item.content:encoded:
Earlier this year @naval posted a long tweetstorm about how to get rich without getting lucky, which blew up. Since then he has posted a series of podcasts expounding on each individual tweet (view it here). Each of these posts provided a more in depth look at what he meant. In this series of posts I will summarize what each podcast covers and write out some actionable take aways I plan on implementing from that particular conversation.

Give Society What it Doesn’t Know how to Get — at scale

When working to create massive wealth, it is the people and companies that identify what society wants and can deliver that to society at scale that will win. When we think about some of today’s most successful companies, we see a similar pattern. Apple perfected the smartphone and then made it accessible to billions of people. Google made the worlds information available to everyone, not just the people who could afford to buy lots of books. Uber brought the world of private car services to the masses.

A common thread among these companies is that the original product was once seen as a luxury that only rich people could afford. These companies came along and made that luxury available to the masses and it so doing, created vast wealth for their shareholders. Some cases, the companies invented an entirely new category that people had not thought of before. Others were an evolution with some defining characteristic that set them apart. In either case, it was opening up the availability that helped propel the wealth creation.

Key Takeaway

Figure out what product you can provide and then figure out how to scale it.

item.title: Live Below Your Means -- My Thoughts
item.description: Earlier this year @naval posted a long tweetstorm about how to get rich without getting lucky, which blew up. Since then he has posted a…
item.content:encoded:
Earlier this year @naval posted a long tweetstorm about how to get rich without getting lucky, which blew up. Since then he has posted a series of podcasts expounding on each individual tweet (view it here). Each of these posts provided a more in depth look at what he meant. In this series of posts I will summarize what each podcast covers and write out some actionable take aways I plan on implementing from that particular conversation.

The most dangerous things are heroin and a monthly salary.

This post has a few things going on in it. Starting out, he talks about lifestyle upgrades and how people tend to upgrade their lifestyles too quickly. We get a raise at work and immediately look for how we can improve our life with that money. Usually, the thing that would improve our lives most, gets overlooked, and that is buying back part of your freedom. Instead, we look at upgrading the car or house. This happens slowly and we don’t really notice the changes while we are making them. But then one day, we’re making $100 an hour and still have no money left.

This is probably the easiest trap we can fall into that prevents us from building true wealth. I know I am guilty of it, I wound up buying three new cars in succession when I was younger. Each one a worse decision than the previous one. Luckily I have started moving past this behavior, but I still find myself wanting to upgrade my life as I grow in my career.

One interesting thing he points out, that I had never thought about, is the ideal way to make a lot of money. If we slowly build up to a very high hourly rate, we still have a hard time accumulating money. However, if we were to instead have some immediate windfall, we wouldn’t have the problem of lifestyle creep. Obviously, we would want to make sure not to spend all of the money we just made, but making these discrete chunks of money usually leaves us better off than slow and steady buildups of hourly wage gains.

Key Takeaway

For this post, I really want to focus on finding ways to just make discrete chunks of money instead of building up my hourly rate.

item.title: Just Do The Work
item.description: I often find myself wanting to write. I’ll be at home, at work or out and about and thing to myself “I really want to just sit down and…
item.content:encoded:
I often find myself wanting to write. I’ll be at home, at work or out and about and thing to myself “I really want to just sit down and write for a bit.” But then I find all sorts of little things to do to avoid writing. Checking Instagram or Twitter. Messing with my LinkedIn profile. Washing the dishes (weird I know). Literally anything to keep from sitting down in front of the computer to actually write something.

Some times, I do get writers block. So I honestly can’t think of the words I want to say when I sit down. This happens to everyone and is completely normal. Usually though, if I force myself to sit there I will start throwing out random thoughts and eventually coalesce into some semi-coherent rambling. This is, from what I hear, the normal writing process for a lot of people. But in these cases, I forced myself to show up and do the work.

How many of us do similar things with other parts of our lives? Wanting a relationship, wanting to get fit, wanting to eat better. We do everything else, saying eventually we’ll get to that hard thing we really want to do.

I recently got myself back in the gym and on a regular workout program, which got me thinking about this topic. I didn’t make any excuses for not going to the gym, but once I got back in, I kept wanting to quit the workout halfway through. But that wouldn’t have given me any progress or satisfaction. So I did the work and I am seeing the results.

This experience reminded me of what I have long known, but tend to forget. We just need to do the work. Instead of putting it off or making excuses or trying to hack our way around the work, just do it. Suck up the short term pain and get it over with. The payoff is always worth the work you have to do.

item.title: You Won't Get Rich Renting Out Your Time -- My Thoughts
item.description: Earlier this year @naval posted a long tweetstorm about how to get rich without getting lucky, which blew up. Since then he has posted a…
item.content:encoded:
Earlier this year @naval posted a long tweetstorm about how to get rich without getting lucky, which blew up. Since then he has posted a series of podcasts expounding on each individual tweet (view it here). Each of these posts provided a more in depth look at what he meant. In this series of posts I will summarize what each podcast covers and write out some actionable take aways I plan on implementing from that particular conversation.

Continuing my exploration of Naval’s thread on how to create wealth, let’s explore his thoughts on renting out your time, aka working for someone else. One of the key things he highlights about working for someone else, is that your compensation is tied directly to your inputs. Every hour you are there, you get some compensation, and no matter how much that hourly compensation is, you only earn it when you show up. Your job won’t pay you while you sleep. It won’t pay you if you take an extended leave of absence. In order to make money during times you aren’t being productive, you have to own a piece of the business. This way, anytime the company makes money, you are making money as well.

Digging a little deeper into inputs vs outputs, it starts to become clear that we need to find an area where our outputs scale non-linearly from our inputs. Creating content, building a digital platform for people to use, creating other software systems. These all scale non-linearly. Your book can reach potentially millions of people, but you don’t have to do any extra work for it to go from one person to a million. This is where his point about mismatched inputs/outputs really comes into play. Even this post, could potentially reach a large audience for just an hour of my time.

A final thing to highlight, he points out that when you rent out your time, you are replaceable. You may be really good at whatever your job is, but there is always someone else who would be willing to do that work. Maybe even at a cheaper price than they are paying you. So it’s really easy to get replaced when you are working for someone else.

Action Items

After reading through his post/thoughts about this, it has given me even more motivation to continue investing in companies and work on pursuing my own opportunities.

item.title: Making Better Decisions with a Radically Open Mind
item.description: How do we make better decisions? What are the biggest hindrances people face when trying to make decisions? In regular life as well as…
item.content:encoded:
How do we make better decisions? What are the biggest hindrances people face when trying to make decisions? In regular life as well as business, it is often viewed that whoever can make the fastest decision will win the situations. In reality, it is whoever makes the best decision quickly who often winds up winning. But what goes into making a better decision? Most companies don’t put time into training their people on how to make better decisions. Most people just go about it the best they can. Stumbling through life making the most optimal decisions they know how. But usually these decisions aren’t the true optimal decision. Our brains have a lot of subliminal ways to hide things we aren’t strong in to protect our ego. We are terrible at recognizing what our blind spots are and this leads us to overconfidence in predicting outcomes of our decisions.

“Well cool Jordan, thanks for completely destroying my fragile mental state already. Do you have any advice on how to get better at this?” -Anyone reading this, probably. Maybe.

Decision making is a very complex process. We take in information, analyze it, make predictions about trends we may see and then use all of that to come to some conclusion. A lot of discussion around decision making focuses on the analysis and prediction portions of this process. Every article out there talking about mental models is really focused on ways to analyze and predict. But what happens if the information supporting that analysis isn’t 100% accurate? How do we know we have good information to begin with? Any analysis or prediction based on faulty information is going to fail, no matter how good the techniques used to make it. How can we dial in on the truth when we seek out information? One promising place to start is with radical open-mindedness.

Radical open-mindedness is a concept Ray Dalio explores a lot in his book Principles. Essentially, it boils down to opening ourselves up to being wrong. Welcoming disagreements as a pursuit of finding out what is true, instead of viewing them as fights to be won. Suspending our ego and accepting that we will not always have the correct answer and that is okay. Focusing on achieving our goal instead of looking good by always having the answer. Finally, reaching out to different experts and having them explain opposing viewpoints to you from their perspective.

Ego and Blind Spots: The Twin Pillars of Terrible Decision Making

Our biggest obstacle in drilling down into what is true, tends to be ourselves. I know, shocking. We’re all amazing thinkers and see things clearly all of the time. Not. Our brains are very good at protecting our ego. Ego, everyone has one but no one wants to admit it. It is that part of us that experiences and reacts to the outside world. It is the part of us that gets bruised when we find out we are wrong. What causes us to cling to ideas, even when we have seen they are incorrect. The ego prevents us from recognizing our blind spots, those areas where we don’t know as much as we think we know. These two combined, ego and blind spots, are our two greatest barriers to finding out what is true.

One of my favorite quotes in this area comes from Ray Dalio. He says:

“Replace your attachment to being right with the joy of learning what’s true.”

I have found this to be a strong guiding light in my own quest for better decisions. Anytime we feel upset during a discussion, we should take a step back and recognize, it is probably stemming from our ego trying to protect us from being hurt. During these moments we need to fight to suspend our ego and accept that maybe you are actually wrong. A lot of times we get caught up in trying to look good, by having the correct answer, but if we don’t actually have the correct answer, we wind up looking bad. We need to shift our focus to simply achieving our goal, and accepting that maybe this time we don’t have the correct answer.

I am still in the process of being radically open-minded, working to suspend my ego and approach situations assuming I am wrong. I am constantly battling old tendencies of assuming I am the smartest person at the table. But I am making progress on it. Share with me your progress on suspending your ego!

item.title: A Brief Catch Up & Currently Reading
item.description: Howdy, y’all!So, June and July have been some hectic months. I moved to Texas, started a new job and have been slowly getting settled in and…
item.content:encoded:
Howdy, y’all!

So, June and July have been some hectic months. I moved to Texas, started a new job and have been slowly getting settled in and exploring my new city. This has kind of put a damper on my energy and focus to write and put out new content. But, I am starting to feel more settled, so I plan on starting to make more time for writing and creating new content for the site.

As part of this, I want to start highlighting some of the items I read each week that really open my eyes. You know, another generic weekly roundup type of blog post. However, I plan on including not only articles, but also books that I am reading and some background information on those books.

I also plan on shifting the focus of the blog from the random software development/personal finance focus I have had to more of a critical thinking/decision analysis focus. I have been reading a lot in both of these areas lately and want to start writing things about them to help myself remember the topics, and if my writing benefits someone else out there then thats even better!

Alright, enough catch up let’s talk about what I’ve been reading.

Blogs
  • Collaborative Fund: So this first one isn’t a particular post, but the overall blog over at Collaborative Fund always has some really interesting articles. Mostly focused on finance, but theres some good gems about overall decision making included.
  • Calculated Risk: I actually found this blog from Collaborative Fund, but it has a lot of really interesting economic data commentary. Not quite focused on decision making, but any decision requires facts to help guide it and he provides some incredible fact based analysis.
  • Naval on Wealth: This is more a series of blog posts and podcasts, which I started writing up key takeaways and action items from, but life got in the way. I may dive back into working on that again, or I may forget it. Either way, you should go read this entire series for yourself. Naval and team provide a lot of powerful takeaways to think about.
Books

So, a few of these are older ones but they still hold a lot of wisdom in them.

  • Principles - Ray Dalio: This is one of the grails for helping make better decisions. He walks through a lot of algorithms anyone can employ to help make better decisions.
  • Stumbling on Happiness - Daniel Gilbert: This is one I have had for a few years and never quite finished. But he walks through a lot of science behind happiness in people and why we are always wrong about what will make us most happy.
  • The Art of Gathering - Priya Parker: This is an excellent discussion about our current problems with meetings and really any other gathering. She walks through great strategies to help improve your future gatherings.
Podcast

I’m not a huge podcast person, but I did listen to a couple recently that had a lot of good points.

  • Financial Independence: The Mad Fientist is a great resource for really streamlining your tax efficiency strategies. This podcast episode he has a very solid conversationn with Ramit Sethi about FIRE and other aspects of saving and spending money.

  • The Joe Rogan Experience: Normally, I’m not a Joe Rogan fan. But this episode with Naval was absolutely brilliant. Expanding on the series I posted in blogs, they do a deep dive on wealth creation in this episode.

    That’s everything!

    I feel like this is starting to get really long, so I’m going to wrap it up. Hopefully you check out some of these resources, if you do, please share how they have impacted you.

item.title: Making Money isn't About Luck -- My Thoughts
item.description: This conversation discusses the concept and role of luck required to become wealthy. There is a common misconception that wealthy people…
item.content:encoded:
*Earlier this year [@naval](https://twitter.com/naval) posted a long tweetstorm about how to get rich without getting lucky, which blew up. Since then he has posted a series of podcasts expounding on each individual tweet (view it [here](https://nav.al/how-to-get-rich#more-28492840)). Each of these posts provided a more in depth look at what he meant. In this series of posts I will summarize what each podcast covers and write out some actionable take aways I plan on implementing from that particular conversation.*

This conversation discusses the concept and role of luck required to become wealthy. There is a common misconception that wealthy people somehow lucked into their wealth, when really a majority of wealthy people got there by working really hard at some craft. Building something that created value for the rest of society.

Naval highlights four types of luck that play different roles in how people can create wealth. The first, blind luck, is what people traditionally credit with making others wealthy. This is the lottery winner, some external event happens that I have no control over that makes me wealthy. Second, we have luck from hustling, where we are always moving, creating opportunities until the right opportunity hits. Third is luck from preparation, which is tied to being skilled in a field and being able to notice when a lucky break happens in that field. Finally there is luck from your unique character, which is weird. It is based on you building a unique character, brand or mindset where then luck finds you. I think the best way to summarize this one is this line “You created your own luck.”

Key Takeaways

We cannot hope that luck will make us wealthy.

We can build a skillset/product where we are in demand, which is a special type of luck.

Wealth stacks up one chip at a time.

Action Items

From this one, my main action item is to continue reading and working on my critical thinking and decision making skills. Along with my software engineering knowledge, eventually this will put me in position to do some incredible work.

*Earlier this year [@naval](https://twitter.com/naval) posted a long tweetstorm about how to get rich without getting lucky, which blew up. Since then he has posted a series of podcasts expounding on each individual tweet (view it [here](https://nav.al/how-to-get-rich#more-28492840)). Each of these posts provided a more in depth look at what he meant. In this series of posts I will summarize what each podcast covers and write out some actionable take aways I plan on implementing from that particular conversation.*

This entry covers the converstaion around free markets and how they are intrinsic to humans. One of the things I have found to be incredible with Naval is how he reframes ideas. This one in particular, I never thought about a conversation as being a value exchange. But he highlights how we as humans inherently track credits and debits, in the context of a conversation. If I am talking to you and feel like I am not getting enough value out of it, I will stop the conversation. He uses this as a parallel to how we operate in the free market. If you have a good or service I want, it will cost me some value to get that good or service.

He also draws comparisons to organic systems, where there are parasites and symbiotes that come together to create a functioning system. Some organisms take nutrients and return a different form of that nutrient, while others just take and take and take. This part of the conversation shifted the focus to groups that despise wealth and want to redistribute it throughout society. They highlight what is happening in Venezuela as the epitome of a society that focused on redistributing wealth without incentivizing the creation of wealth.

Key Takeaways

Humanity is the only species that keeps track of credits/debits. This inherent tracking is the same as free markets.

Action Items

I think, for me, the biggest action item I have from this one is just going to be focusing on bringing equal value to every transaction I participate in.

item.content:encoded:
Earlier this year @naval posted a long tweetstorm about how to get rich without getting lucky, which blew up. Since then he has posted a series of podcasts expounding on each individual tweet (view it here). Each of these posts provided a more in depth look at what he meant. In this series of posts I will summarize what each podcast covers and write out some actionable take aways I plan on implementing from that particular conversation.

This converstaion was very interesting to me. As someone who grew up in a blue collar family, there was almost this taboo about wanting to be rich. There was this belief that rich people stole their wealth from someone else. Looking at wealth as a fixed quantity, not as something that can be increased across all of humanity. Naval highlights how this is an incorrect view of the economy, that in fact the economy can continue increasing in size as people start adding newer things of value to the overall system.

Key Takeaways

Wealth is not a zero sum game.

True wealth creates abundance for the world.

When we look at building wealth as adding new things of value to the world, we no longer have to think about how we can “trick” someone out of their money. We can instead start looking for holes that need to be filled. Anytime we think, “there should be a different way to do this,” we should instantly start ideating on that. Trying to identify why it is frustrating to us and how we can reduce or remove that frustration.

Action Items

For me, I think the paragraph above really sums up what my action item is going to be from this particular tweet:

Look for pain points in life and try to solve them.

item.title: Seek Wealth, Not Money or Status - My Thoughts
item.description: Earlier this year @naval posted a long tweetstorm about how to get rich without getting lucky, which blew up. Since then he has posted a…
item.content:encoded:
Earlier this year @naval posted a long tweetstorm about how to get rich without getting lucky, which blew up. Since then he has posted a series of podcasts expounding on each individual tweet (view it here). Each of these posts provided a more in depth look at what he meant. In this series of posts I will summarize what each podcast covers and write out some actionable take aways I plan on implementing from that particular conversation.

This first discussion is focused on differentiating between wealth, money and status. Often people tend to mix these three up and view them as interchangable. Obviously someone who attends high status social events will be wealthy and have a lot of money. Instead of just applying that blanket thought to all three, we should actually look at what each one really is. Naval provides a great definition for each of these:

Wealth is assets that earn while you sleep.

Money is how we transfer wealth.

Status is your rank in the social hierarchy.

The conversation around these concepts is very good and I would encourage you to listen to the full recording, it’s only six minutes long. But today I want to just highlight a few take aways I had and then provide a few ways I plan on putting these concepts into practice.

Key Takeaways

Focus on creating wealth, instead of getting caught up in the typical status games people play. Status games are inherently zero-sum games which means there will be a winner and a loser. Focusing on these games will satisfy our baser instincts, but will rarely have material impacts on our ability to achieve freedom.

Money is a wealth transfer based on the time we put into something. When we create wealth for ourselves, we are buying back time to spend on things we are interested in.

We can classify a lot of the keeping up with the Joneses and FOMO spending as status seeking behavior. We all want the nice car or house to signal to the world we are doing “well” at the career/economic game.

Action Items

Build something of my own. I have had an itch to create my own business for a while, but I never knew what to do. I need to make a leap and try something, even if it is a simple coaching side hustle.

Increase investment. Over the past few years I have been slowly increasing the portion of my income I dedicate to investment. I need to ramp that up even more now.

Remove status from my value equations. It doesn’t matter what type of car I drive or what the size of my house/apartment is. I am not trying to be better than anyone else based on the material posessions I own.

item.title: Daily Algorithm Practice - Valid Parentheses
item.description: Problem StatementGiven a string containing just the characters ’(’, ’)’, ’{’,’}’, ’’, ’’, determine if the input string is valid. An input…
item.content:encoded:
Problem Statement

Given a string containing just the characters ’(’, ’)’, ’{’,’}’, ’[’, ’]’, determine if the input string is valid. An input string is valid if:

  • Open brackets must be closed by the same type of bracket.
  • Open brackets must be closed in the correct order. Note that an empty string is also considered valid.

Description of Algorithm

For this implementation, we will be sacrificing some memory space to speed up our algorithm. The basic logic of the algorithm is:

  • For each character in the string

    • We check if it is in a dictionary of closing parentheses.

      • If so, we then remove the top item from a stack if present, or use a placeholder value

      • We then check if the pair value of the current character in our dictionary is the same as what we removed from the stack.

        • If it is not, we return False because there is one closing parenthesis that does not have a matching opening one.
    • If the item is not a closing parenthesis, we then push it to our stack
  • After reviewing each item in the string, we return whether the stack is empty, which will tell us whether there were any spare opening parenthesis.

Algorithm in Code

def isValid(s: string) -> bool:
    stack = []
    mapping = {")": "(", "}": "{", "]": "[" }

    for char in s:
        if char in mapping:
            top_element = stack.pop() if stack else '#'
            if mapping[char] != top_element:
                return False
        else:
            stack.append(char)

    return not stack

Walkthrough of Algorithm

Starting at the top of our code, we have:

stack = []
mapping = {")":"(", "}": "{", "]":"["}

This section just creates our extra data structures we will use to store our opening parentheses as we progress through and the dictionary mapping our closing parentheses to the correct opening one.

for char in s:

This sets up our iteration through the string.

if char in mapping:
    top_element = stack.pop() if stack else '#'
    if mapping[char] != top_element:
        return False

This code chunk is the logic that looks up each char to see if it is a key in our dictionary of closing parentheses. If it is, we remove the top element of our stack, if there is any, or create a placeholder value if the stack is empty. If this top_element is not the same as the value corresponding to the char key in our dictionary, we know there is one closing parenthesis that does not have a matching opening parenthesis. So we return False.

else:
    stack.append(char)

Here, we know that the char is an opening parenthesis so we add it to our stack.

return not stack

This line can be tricky, the logic for it is below:

  • First check if there is anything left on the stack.

    • If there is, we get a True value
    • If there is not, we get a False value
  • We then take that True or False value and negate it with the not keyword.

  • Finally we return that negation. This process works because, if there is anything on the stack we know that there was at least one opening parenthesis that did not have a corresponding closing parenthesis. This means our string was not valid, so returning not True gives us the correct evaluation.

    Conclusion

    This algorithm is efficient in time, as we only need to make one pass through the entire string to determine if it is valid. We also will require, at worst, n space if we push all elements onto our stack. In this case, the trade off in space for less time complexity is a benefit.

item.title: Daily Algorithm Practice - Remove Elements From a Linked List
item.description: Problem StatementRemove all elements from a linked list of integers that have value val.Example:Input = 1 -> 2 -> 6 -> 3 -> 4 -> 5 -> 6val…
item.content:encoded:
Problem Statement

Remove all elements from a linked list of integers that have value val.

Example:

Input = 1 -> 2 -> 6 -> 3 -> 4 -> 5 -> 6

val = 6

Output = 1 -> 2 -> 3 -> 4 -> 5

Node definition for singly linked lists

class ListNode:
    def __init__(self, x):
        self.val = x
        self.next = None

Description of Algorithm

In this problem we will have two separate portions of the algorithm. The first will check if the head of our list is the value we need to remove. The second portion will walk through the list to find and remove any other elements with the value we are looking for. To do this, we will always check the value of element.next. This way we won’t lose our place in the list.

Algorithm in Code

def removeElements(head, val):
    while head and head.val == val:
        head = head.next
    cur = head
    while cur:
        while cur.next and cur.next.val == val:
            cur.next = cur.next.next
        cur = cur.next
    return head

Walkthrough of Algorithm

Let’s walk through this code and see what it’s doing.

while head and head.val == val:
    head = head.next

Here, we look at the head element of our list and if the value of it is equal to the value we are looking for, we skip the element and move to the next item in the list.

cur = head
while cur:

Here, we create a new variable, cur and assign the value of head to it. Then, as long as there is a value assigned to cur we iterate through the next portion of our code.

while cur.next and cur.next.next.val == val:
    cur.next = cur.next.next

This section is where we check if there is a value in the next node and if the value in the node after that is equal to the value we are excluding. If both of those conditions are true, we skip the item after the next node.

cur = cur.next

Here we are simply advancing to the next node in our list.

return head

Finally, we return the head element of our linked list.

Conclusion

With this algorithm, we simply have to make one pass through our linked list to remove any nodes with our target value. Additionally, we do not require any extra memory to do this, as we are using the existing nodes and simply changing which node is stored as the next node for any nodes preceding ones with the target value.

item.title: Daily Algorithm Practice - Merge Sorted Linked Lists
item.description: Problem StatementMerge two sorted linked lists and return it as a new list. The new list should be made by splicing together the nodes of…
item.content:encoded:
Problem Statement

Merge two sorted linked lists and return it as a new list. The new list should be made by splicing together the nodes of the first two lists.

This problem has us exploring the properties of linked lists and how we can leverage them to efficiently merge two already sorted linked lists given each lists first element.

Description of Algorithm

Our general algorithm is structured as below:

  • Compare first values of each list to determine which is smaller
  • Set that item as the first item of our new linked list
  • Progress to the next item on that list and compare it to the item on the other list.
  • Set the smaller one as the next value of our first item
  • Repeat this procedure until we are out of items on both lists.

Node definition for singly linked lists:

class ListNode:
    def __init__(self, x):
        self.val = x
        self.next = None

Algorithm in Code

def mergeTwoLists(self, l1: ListNode, l2: ListNode) -> ListNode:
        if not l1:
            return l2
        elif not l2:
            return l1
        dummy = ListNode(None)
        curr = dummy
        while l1 or l2:
            if l1 and (not l2 or l1.val < l2.val):
                curr.next = l1
                l1 = l1.next
            else:
                curr.next = l2
                l2 = l2.next
            curr = curr.next
        return dummy.next

Code Walkthrough

Let’s dive in and explore the code line by line.

if not l1:
    return l2
elif not l2:
    return l1

These first few lines of code are checking that both l1 and l2 have values in them. If either of them are empty, we simply return the first node of the other list.

dummy = listNode(None)
curr = dummy

This block sets up some placeholder variables we will use later on in our algorithm. We create an empty Node called dummy and then set curr equal to that empty Node.

while l1 or l2:

This portion sets up our loop which will continue processing until l1 and l2 have no more values.

if l1 and (not l2 or l1.val < l2.val):
    curr.next = l1
    l1 = l1.next

This if statement is a little tricky so I am going to attempt to write it out as plainly as possible. The logic for it follows:

  • If l1 has a value

    • And l2 has a value

      • And value of l1 is less than value of l2

        • We set the next node of curr equal to l1 node and then replace l1 with the next node on list1.
else:
    curr.next = l2
    l2 = l2.next

If l1 has no value or l2 value is greater than l1 value, we make the next node of curr equal to l2 and then advance l2 to the next node on list2.

curr = curr.next

We then advance the value of curr to the next node we just added to the list.

return dummy.next

Finally, we return dummy.next which is the first value of our newly created linked list.

Conclusion

This algorithm is an intuitive method for iteratively building up a linked list based on two separate, sorted linked lists. We used the built in features of storing the next node of our list to make a linear time complexity algorithm and only had to compare the current node values to ensure our sort was correct.

Thanks for reading along and feel free to reach out via social if you want to chat!

item.title: Can We Build a Mentality of Saving in a World Constantly Pushing us to Spend?
item.description: 59 Percent of Americans consider themselves savers, yet only 38 percent have an emergency fund.I was reading through the Schwab 2019 Modern…
item.content:encoded:
59 Percent of Americans consider themselves savers, yet only 38 percent have an emergency fund.

I was reading through the Schwab 2019 Modern Wealth Survey recently and I saw the above highlights, which really blew my mind. How can we claim 59 percent of the population are savers, but less than 40 percent can cover an emergency?

Don’t get me wrong, I can understand people who classify themselves as savers but find themselves without anything extra in the bank at the end of the month. I was in that boat for a long time too. I always planned on putting money into my savings, some months actually putting the money in the account, but then a bill would come up that required me pulling that money out and spending it. In my case, I had built up an unsustainable level of monthly expenses, through housing costs, car loans and credit card debt, that I didn’t have enough money coming in each month to allow me to put money away.

After getting my car loans and credit card debt sorted out, one of the things that helped me cut back on extraneous spending which allowed me to start building up a savings cushion was this mindset shift, focusing my spending on things that I deeply valued. I realized I had been spending money on so many random things; new clothes, nights out at the bar, various electronic trinkets but none of these items were truly things that I valued and brought a lot of joy to my life. So I sat down and spent some time identifying the areas of my life that brought out the most joy for me. Kind of applying Marie Kondo’s “spark joy” thought process to my finances.

Once I identified the top three areas of life that sparked joy in me, I sat down and started allocating money into these areas. Every month I have a note in my phone with my major spending areas and the total amount I can spend in that area for the month. As I make purchases, I subtract that amount from the overall balance for that category and make sure I stay above zero there.

clearly I spend a lot of money on food and coffee…

Now, this money is separate from what I need to pay my monthly bills and I also consider saving as a “bill” that I have to pay every month. Doing this for every category of spending you have each month would be helpful as a first step towards wrangling your spending habits.

How does this help?

In the report from Schwab, a third of Americans claim negative influence from social media as causing them to overspend. Amongst millennials and Gen z members, that amount jumps to almost half. But if we have a framework of spending money on the things that bring us the most joy and have identified what those areas are, we can remind ourselves as we scroll through Instagram that all these pictures from our friends don’t necessarily align with our areas of joy. If we don’t value fancy cocktails, then Chad’s post of the awesome drinks he’s having won’t have the same influence. If we don’t value fashion, Becky can post all of the dresses and shoes she wants, but we wont feel pressured to go buy them.

In the battle to build financial security in our lives, aligning our spending with what we truly value in life is a pretty powerful tool we should implement. What areas do you find bring you the most joy per buck?

item.title: Daily Algorithm Practice - Merge Sorted Lists
item.description: Problem StatementGiven two sorted number arrays, nums1 and nums2, merge nums2 into nums1 as one sorted array.We are given m and n which…
item.content:encoded:
Problem Statement

Given two sorted number arrays, nums1 and nums2, merge nums2 into nums1 as one sorted array.

We are given m and n which represent the initialized elements in nums1 and nums2 respectively. We may assume that nums1 was initialized with enough space to fit all values from nums2.

Example input:

  • nums1 = [1,2,3,0,0,0] m = 3
  • nums2 = [2,5,6] n = 3

Description of Algorithm

One method of doing this is to brute force our way through the arrays. The pseudocode would look like:

  • Look at first item in nums1
  • compare to first item in nums2
  • if smaller, go to next item in nums1
  • if larger, move nums1 item one to the right, insert nums2 item one.

This would progress through each item in each list until they are all in place. This is extremely inefficient however.

A better algorithm would use the fact that they are already sorted smallest to largest and that we know the total length nums1 will be after merging, m+n. With this, we can start at the end of both lists, comparing values and replacing values as we go. Pseudocode:

  • Look at last sorted element in nums1
  • compare to last element in nums2
  • if larger, move to end of nums1 array
  • if smaller, remove nums2 element and place in last spot of nums1
  • decrease size of m and n

Algorithm in Code

def merge(self, nums1: List[int], m: int, nums2: List[int], n: int) -> None:
    if nums2:
        while nums2:
            if m>0 and nums1[m-1] > nums2[n-1]:
                nums1[m+n-1] = nums1[m-1]
                m -= 1
            else:
                nums1[m+n-1] = nums2.pop()
                n -= 1

Code Walkthrough

Diving into our algorithm line by line (skipping the function definition) we have:

if nums2:

Here we are checking to make sure there is an initial value in nums2.

while nums2:

This sets up our iterative loop that lasts as long as there is a value left in nums2.

if m>0 and nums1[m-1] > nums2[n-1]:
    nums1[m+n-1] = nums1[m-1]
    m -= 1

This portion checks to make sure m is greater than zero and compares the last sorted value in nums1 to the final value in nums2. If the final sorted value of nums1 is larger than the final value in nums2, we know that that value is the largest value in the final array. So we move that value to the end of nums1 and leave the final value of nums2 in place. Finally we decrement m by 1.

else:
    nums1[m+n-1] = nums2.pop()
    n -= 1

This branch of our if-else statement means the last value of nums2 is larger than the last sorted value of nums1, which means it is the largest value of our final sorted array. So we pop it off nums2 and assign it to the final position in nums1. We then decrement n by 1.

This will continue looping until we pop off the final value of nums2.

Conclusion

This algorithm is a great example of how we can leverage some of the extra knowledge we may have about a problem to come up with a more efficient solution to algorithm problems. In this case, we knew that each array was already sorted and that the first array had zeroes for the last n elements.

Thanks for following along. Please reach out to me via social with any questions or comments.

item.title: Daily Algorithm Work May 23, 2019
item.description: Problem Statement:Consider all the leaves of a binary tree. From left to right order, the values of those leaves form a leaf value sequence…
item.content:encoded:
Problem Statement:

Consider all the leaves of a binary tree. From left to right order, the values of those leaves form a leaf value sequence.

For example, in the given tree above, the leaf value sequence is (6, 7, 4, 9, 8).

Two binary trees are considered leaf-similar if their leaf value sequence is the same.

Return true if and only if the two given trees with head nodes root1 and root2 are leaf-similar.

Solution Description:

This problem is a variation of a depth first search problem. In this implementation of DFS, we need to build out our list of leaf nodes for each root node and then compare these lists to see if they are equivalent. The code implementation of this is below (language used is Python).

def leafSimilar(root1, root2):
        def dfs(node):
            if node:
                if not node.left and not node.right:
                    yield node.val
                yield from dfs(node.left)
                yield from dfs(node.right)

        return list(dfs(root1)) == list(dfs(root2))

Above we have the implementation, now let’s walk through it to look under the hood a little. We will skip over the def lines and jump straight into the good parts.

 if not node.left and not node.right:
     yield node.val

This chunk is our base case test: if there is a value in either node.left or node.right, this node is not a leaf. If there are no values in either node.left or node.right, we yield the value of the node. Note the use of yield here instead of return, this allows us to pass a value while still maintaining state.

yield from dfs(node.left)
yield from dfs(node.right)

This chunk is the heart of our recursive call. The first line passes the left child of the node into our depth first search function while the second line passes the right child. 

  return list(dfs(root1)) == list(dfs(root2))

This is the final line, where we call our dfs function with our two root values. Wrapping the dfs function in the list method allows us to build out a list of all the leaf nodes that are yielded from our function (the main reason we used yield instead of return in our function). Once both lists have been built, we check if they are equivalent, finally returning True or False based on that check.

item.title: Missing Places
item.description: As I was sitting in a hip taco spot in downtown Boise this past weekend, I started reflecting on what this city means to me. Growing up, I…
item.content:encoded:
As I was sitting in a hip taco spot in downtown Boise this past weekend, I started reflecting on what this city means to me. Growing up, I never really had a hometown, bouncing from city to city, state to state and even country to country meant nowhere gave me that feeling of “home”. Until I moved to Boise for my undergrad.

A few years ago, after spending 10 years here, I moved away for a new job opportunity. For the first year, I had this hole in me, which I attributed to just missing the city of Boise and not settling in to my new location. As time went on, I still felt that hole. It got to a point where I realized it wasn’t just missing the city. There was a feeling my memories of Boise brought up that had nothing to do with a specific location.

The more I thought about it, I realized it wasn’t just the city itself. It was the community of people I was able to build while living there. Between friends from my undergrad days, people I met at crossfit and colleagues who became friends, I had an amazing community of people that really made my time in Boise feel like home.

Our brains are incredibly powerful. This feeling that is associated to a place affects how I picture the city when I think about it. As time has passed, the people who made up that community have moved on with their lives, taking them out of the city. Physically, the city itself has changed with a lot of development happening while I’ve been away. These two factors combine together so every time I come back it feels less and less like the place I remember. More often, I find myself wondering if this is still the same city I originally fell in love with.

What is the place that gives you that feeling of home? Do you find it being more related to the people you have there or the actual physical space?
